Award.AwardTitle: Arterial wall viscoelasticity and cardiovascular networks
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project develops mathematical and computational models of the cardiovascular system that couple dynamics of blood flow to vessel wall viscoelasticity at the scale of individual vessel segments and vessel networks. The project design integrates novel mathematical modeling, new numerical techniques for soft tissue viscoelasticity, and extensive data analysis via collaboration with experimentalists at the Republic University, Montevideo, Uruguay. Models of both individual vessel segments and networks of multiple vessels will be developed in coordination with a systematic analysis of experimental data that employs parameter estimation and sensitivity analysis techniques. The highly integrative and interdisciplinary nature of this study will yield outcomes that can lead to new standards for modeling cardiovascular dynamics in vessel networks. In particular, the importance of arterial wall viscoelasticity will be analyzed according to vessel location and type, species (sheep, humans) and experimental conditions (in-vivo, ex-vivo). In addition, effects of disease will be simulated with an emphasis on variables of clinical relevance. The models developed in this project will facilitate accurate prediction of waveforms for blood flow, blood pressure, and vessel cross-sectional area in cardiovascular networks.

This project develops a novel, integrative approach to analyzing cardiovascular dynamics both in single vessels as well as vessel networks by coordinating mathematical and computational modeling with a systematic and comprehensive approach to analysis of experimental data. Present approaches rely on models that neglect energy loss (viscoelasticity) in the deformation of individual vessel walls, or models that do not consider downstream effects on blood pressure, blood flow, and vessel cross-sectional area in cardiovascular networks of blood vessels. The models developed in this project will be assessed, calibrated and refined in coordination with experimental collaborators allowing analysis of data from varying experimental conditions, different species (sheep, human), and in different states of health (healthy vs. hypertensives). The techniques and outcomes of this project have the potential for setting a new standard in modeling cardiovascular blood flow and can also be applied to study effects of other diseases (e.g., diabetes) that significantly affect cardiovascular health. The models of vessel networks developed in this project have the potential to provide clinicians with a reference library of blood pressure waveforms that can be incorporated into medical simulators and databases for diagnostic applications in cardiovascular medicine.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goal of this study was to investigate how to predict deformation of the arterial wall within cardiovascular models of the systemic and pulmonary circulations. This is important, in particular, to understand how modulation of the vessel wall impacts blood pressure waveforms in hypertension. A specific focus of this  project was to incorporate viscoelasticty into models for deformation of the vessel wall. In the systemic circulation we investigated the relative importance of viscosity, viscoelasticity and nonlinear elastic deformation as well as developed a method for predicting inflow given data for pressure and area in the center of the vessel. These models were validated against data from sheep. Results show that nonlinear elastic deformation is important in large vessels with a high content of elastin whereas linear elastic  deformation is sufficient to model the smaller vessels.  We also demonstrate that model predictions are highly sensitive to the balance of energy dissipation mechanims captured via the wall viscoelasticity versus the lumped boundary conditions that model the downstream vessel network.  Our results lay a foundation for future studies that will aim to more precisely delineate the relative contribution of these two important energy loss mechanisms.

In addition, we studied elastic deformaiton in the pulmonary circulation. For this study we investigated the relative importance of changing elastic properties of the large vs. the small vessels, as well as the impact of rarefaction within the microvascular network. These three characteristics are of importance since they characterize different forms of pulmonary hypertension. In our next study, we will move on to study how vessels are remodelled during disease progression. There is currently no cure for pulmonary hypertension, and invasive pressure tests are associated with risk to the patient. Therefore, having better models predicting dynamics associated with this disease have potential to aid in the development of better diagnosis methods relaying more on noninvasive techniques versus riskier and more costly invasive pressure measurements. 

Finally, we studied the importance of accounting for viscoelastic deformation when modeling baroreflex response and cerebral autoregulation during postural change. These tests are often applied to understand if and how subjects can control blood pressure to avoid fainting during postural change This is typically tested using head-up tilt protocols. Results from this study contribute to understanding how and if the control is modulated in patients with hypertension. Our results on cerebral autoregulation were among the first to show that the system is changed in hypertension.
